title: 8 Lactoferrin Health Benefits + Sources & Side Effects - SelfDecode Supplements
author: Aleksa Ristic
description: Lactoferrin supports immunity and iron absorption. Learn the benefits of supplementation, food sources, and side effects.
cleaned_text: naturally occurring protein found in milk and bodily fluids. It is a potent anti-microbial and modulator of the immune system. As a supplement, lactoferrin may improve iron status, skin health, immunity, and more. Read this post to learn the health benefits of lactoferrin, along with food sources & side effects. What is Lactoferrin? Lactoferrin (also known as lactotransferrin or LF) is a type of iron-binding glycoprotein that is mostly secreted from bodily fluids including milk, saliva, tears, vaginal fluids, [semen](https://selfhacked.com/blog/unhealthy-ejaculate/), secretions from lungs and nose, [bile](https://selfhacked.com/blog/bile-supplements/), digestive juices, and urine [ [1](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1793702/)]. It provides antibacterial and immune-supporting activity to human infants. LF is a component of the immune system responsible for defense at the mucosal level, due to its high antimicrobial activity. Lactoferrin is crucial to the increase in immune functions for breastfed infants. It is also believed to be widely important to maintaining immune functions further in life past infancy. Lactoferrin is also found in secondary [neutrophil](https://selfhacked.com/blog/neutrophils/) granules, blood, and amniotic fluid. It also binds to DNA and other molecules in milk like IgA, casein, [albumin](https://selfhacked.com/blog/albumin/), etc. [ [2](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27690059), [1](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1793702/)]. It helps develop the gastrointestinal and immune system in newborns [ [3](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27234407)]. The iron-bound form of lactoferrin is called holo-lactoferrin, whereas the lactoferrin without iron is apo-lactoferrin. Snapshot Proponents: - Helps the immune system and prevents inflammation - Has anti-cancer properties - Supports iron absorption - Shields preterm infants - Anti-bacterial, anti-fungal, anti-viral - Promotes bone health Skeptics: - High doses may cause digestive upset - Supplementation is not well studied in humans Marker of Inflammation and Infections Lactoferrin kills bacteria and protects from infections. Therefore, natural lactoferrin levels in our bodies rise during times of infections and inflammation. To combat bacterial infections, blood lactoferrin rapidly rises and iron levels drop during E. coli infection in the blood in mice [ [4](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2694351/)]. Doctors test lactoferrin in the stool to detect inflammation in the intestines, especially to diagnose inflammatory bowel disease [ [5](https://labtestsonline.org/understanding/analytes/lactoferrin/tab/test/)]. Fecal lactoferrin levels also naturally rise in the case of Clostridium difficile infections in humans [ [6](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3825630/)]. Antioxidant Properties Because iron can cause [oxidative stress](https://selfhacked.com/blog/oxidative-stress-101/), lactoferrin can reduce oxidative stress by binding and removing iron, which prevents cell damage or cell death [ [7](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2915836/)]. Lactoferrin supplementation can support the immune system as an antioxidant [ [8](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19083463)]. Roles in Immunity There are lactoferrin receptors on many immune cells, so lactoferrin directly affects how these cells function [ [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16261254), [ 10](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8525969), [ 11](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7762450)]. Lactoferrin can exert changes through increasing [natural killer cell](http://selfhacked.com/blog/intro-natural-killer-cells-increase-decrease/), [neutrophils](https://selfhacked.com/blog/neutrophils/), and macrophage activities. This increases cytokine, and Nitric Oxide production as well as limit pathogen growth [ [12](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9606986), [ 13](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9682001), [ 14](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2276410/)]. Lactoferrin also affects adaptive immune cells (T-cells and B-cells) [ [15](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9781377)]. In infants, lactoferrin is crucial to the development of their natural immune system function to prevent infection [ [16](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27234411)]. Anti-Inflammatory Effects Although the direct mechanism has not been established yet, lactoferrin is a well-known anti-inflammatory component in humans [ [17](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16261255)]. Lactoferrin in the amniotic fluid is an important component to reducing fetal inflammation in pregnant women through reducing [IL-6](http://selfhacked.com/blog/interleukin-6/) levels and reducing infection causing the inflammation [ [18](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10195738)]. It has anti-inflammatory properties when interacting with the immune system against the Epstein-Barr virus, reducing inflammation by inhibiting the activation of TLR2 and [TLR9](https://selfdecode.com/gene/tlr9/?utm_source=seo&utm_medium=selfhacked&utm_campaign=id00002) in the virus DNA [ [19](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25068657)]. Antibacterial Properties Lactoferrin helps stop the activity of bacteria. Most bacteria need iron to function, and lactoferrin can stop bacteria from taking up iron in the human body [ [1](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1793702/)]. In addition to this, it can block bacteria's carbohydrate metabolism, destabilize their cell walls, or interact with lysozymes in milk to stop bacteria [ [1](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1793702/)]. Roles in Fetal/Infant Development Infants require lactoferrin to develop and adapt to the intestinal system. It is responsible for differentiating small intestinal epithelial cells, affecting small intestinal mass, length, and enzyme expression [ [20](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22332905)]. In human fetuses, lactoferrin serves as a bone growth regulator in the early phases of human bone development [ [21](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20972893)]. Lactoferrin promotes cartilaginous tissue growth at various stages of fetal development by stimulating immature osteocytes and osteoblasts [ [22](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20443779)]. In human fetuses, LF promotes iron absorption and development of the brush border, allowing for healthy growth and gut development before birth [ [23](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1659221)]. High levels of LF in the fetus prevent infection and ruptures of fetal membranes while increasing the ease of labor [ [24](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11035335)]. Health Benefits of Lactoferrin Supplementation Possibly Effective: 1) Iron Deficiency in Pregnancy Lactoferrin helps increase iron absorption in the intestine. It is also responsible for the delivery of iron to cells. According to a meta-analysis of four clinical trials and 600 pregnant women, "oral bovine lactoferrin is just as good as ferrous sulfate in improving hematological parameters with fewer gastrointestinal side effects." Lactoferrin showed better effects on hemoglobin levels in pregnant women with moderate anemia [ [25](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29059584)]. 2) Premature Delivery Risks Many preterm babies suffer from necrotizing enterocolitis when bacteria can destroy the intestinal walls and cause the intestinal cells to die [ [26](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3579561/)]. Preliminary reports suggested that human and bovine lactotransferrin can kill bacteria in the intestines and help stop necrotizing enterocolitis. A study of 743 preterm infants confirmed these findings [ [26](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3579561/), [ 27](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24709463)]. Lactoferrin is naturally found in breast milk in high amounts, which is another reason why breastfeeding is essential for infant development [ [28](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6163804/)]. Additionally, lactoferrin (oral and intravaginal) stopped the shortening of the cervical length, reduced uterine contractions, and prevented vaginal infections in two clinical trials [ [29](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22292525), [30](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21922138)]. 3) Skin Health 36 young adults were given milk with lactoferrin and their skin condition improved. They had less acne and skin inflammation compared to the placebo group [ [31](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20692602)]. 22 psoriasis patients also benefited from topical application. The redness and size of their skin lesions improved after applying 10% or 20% LF cream (equally effective) [ [32](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24819761)]. In 55 diabetic patients, topical applications of recombinant lactoferrin improved the healing of foot ulcers with no side effects [ [33](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17188087)]. 4) Hepatitis C In a preliminary study of 11 patients with chronic hepatitis C (CHC), an 8week treatment of bovine lactoferrin (1.8 or 3.6 g/day) significantly reduced serum alanine transaminase (ALT) and the viral RNA in patients with milder forms of infection [ [34](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5926088/)]. The same group of researchers then conducted a placebo-controlled trial of 63 CHC patients. They found that bovine lactoferrin (600 mg/day) produce a Th1-cytokine dominant environment (IL-4 and IFN-gamma), which supports the IFN therapy for hepatitis C [ [35](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12697243/)]. Two additional studies of 310 CHC patients confirmed that lactoferrin may increase the effectiveness of standard treatment, but doesn't have therapeutic properties on its own [ [36](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16984383/), [37](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17914966/)]. Insufficient Evidence: No valid clinical evidence supports the use of lactoferrin for any of the conditions in this section. Below is a summary of up-to-date animal studies, cell-based research, or low-quality clinical trials which should spark further investigation. However, you shouldn't interpret them as supportive of any health benefit. 5) Cancer Treatment Support Lactoferrin supports the immune system by activating microbe- and cancer-fighting cells such as natural killer (NK) cells and T lymphocytes. Researchers have developed human recombinant lactoferrin, talactoferrin, that showed promising results as a drug candidate [ [38](https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-drug/def/talactoferrin)]. In a study of 110 patients with advanced or metastatic lung cancer, talactoferrin significantly improved the effectiveness of standard treatment (carboplatin + paclitaxel) [ [39](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21532506)]. Talactoferrin significantly improved survival in a trial of 100 patients with chemotherapy-resistant lung cancer. However, it didn't show significant benefits for the same condition in a much larger study of 742 patients [ [40](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21969509), [41](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24050956)]. Ten lung cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy had increased immune system response after taking lactoferrin post-treatment [ [42](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23847257)]. In rats, supplementation of bovine lactoferrin interacted with phase 1 enzymes to reduce the carcinogenic effects of lung, bladder, tongue, colon, and liver cancer. It also had the ability to restore white and red blood cell count after chemotherapy ( [43](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21622257), [44](http://www.nutritionjrnl.com/article/S0899-9007(06)00236-X/abstract)). Bovine lactotransferrin decreases breast cancer cell viability and cell growth, and increased cell death in a couple of cell-based studies [ [45](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21183018), [46](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25406879)]. Larger, well-designed clinical trials should investigate the anticancer effects of lactoferrin. At this point, it can't be recommended for cancer treatment or prevention. 6) Weight Loss Obese Japanese men and women (n=26) were given lactoferrin tablets (300 mg) for eight weeks. The treatment reduced their fat mass, body weight (-1.5 kg), BMI, and hip circumference (-2.6 cm) [ [47](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20691130)]. Lactoferrin appears to control fat accumulation in humans. There is also some evidence that iron deficiency might contribute to obesity, but more studies need to be done [ [48](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26981846)]. Further research is needed to confirm the benefits of lactoferrin for weight control. Caloric restriction and regular exercise remain the best approach that no supplements can replace. 7) Digestive Support In a study of 32 Japanese women, LF suppressed the growth of E. coli and Salmonella while promoting the growth of beneficial Bifidobacteria. As a result, the treatment significantly improved digestion and relieved constipation [ [49](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24936358)]. 8) Bone Health In 38 postmenopausal women, RNAse-enriched lactoferrin supplementation significantly improved their bone health and stimulated bone formation. More research is needed to make definite conclusions [ [50](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19172341)]. Animal and Cellular Research (Lacking Evidence) No clinical evidence supports the use of lactoferrin for any of the conditions listed in this section. Below is a summary of the existing animal and cell-based research, which should guide further investigational efforts. However, the studies listed below should not be interpreted as supportive of any health benefit. Bacterial Infections In animals with bacterial LPS toxicity, injecting them with lactoferrin reduces many symptoms of toxicity, and reduce risks of death from LPS toxicity by five-fold [ [51](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9781356), [ 52](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10704062)]. Lactoferrin and lysozyme prevented the spread of Streptococcus pneumoniae to sterile cells in a cell-based study [ [53](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26298002)]. In mice infected with Listeria monocytogenes, treatment with lactoferrin boosted the immune function and decreased the overall level of invading bacteria [ [54](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20348006)]. In test tubes, human lactoferrin taken alongside iron supplementation was successful in fighting Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae infection by inhibiting the growth and spread of the bacteria [ [55](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24878848)]. Viral Infections In human cell cultures, lactoferrin can prevent viruses from entering human cells by blocking cellular receptors or directly binding to the viruses [ [56](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21847071)]. The bovine lactoferrin was more efficient than the human version in stopping the herpes virus in human cell culture. However, both types were able to stop the virus from entering the cells [ [56](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21847071)]. Lactoferrin was also effective in stopping the effects of HIV by blocking the entry process in vitro [ [56](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21847071)]. In human cells, lactoferrin also inhibited hepatitis B, HPV, rotavirus, HSV, and influenza by using similar mechanisms [ [56](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21847071)]. Other Infections Fungi Both bovine (cow) and human lactoferrin stopped the growth of fungi in human cell cultures [ [57](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11020255/)]. Parasites In cows infected with a parasite, lactoferrin supplementation increases the immune system response to the parasite, helping to expel it from the body [ [58](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26251568)]. Allergies and Asthma Lactoferrin helped reduce airway inflammation in a mouse asthma model [ [59](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16800860/)]. In test tubes, it blocked [histamine](http://selfhacked.com/blog/histamine/) release from colon mast cells [ [60](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4724932/)]. Brain Development In a study on piglets, lactoferrin helped improve cognition and brain development. They learned how to complete learning tasks more efficiently [ [61](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4510916/)]. Lactoferrin Side Effects Lactoferrin is safe and well-tolerated; high doses (>1,100 mg a day) might cause some abdominal pain, diarrhea, or constipation [ [62](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19639462)]. In some human subjects, injections of 5 mg of LF may increase liver enzymes. Further studies will be needed to test the safety of LF injections in humans [ [63](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2746231/)]. Lactoferrin Sources and Digestion Raw vs Pasteurized Milk Lactoferrin is heat stable and may survive pasteurization, but not high-pressure treatment [ [64](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22281319)]. 5 studies have shown that there is no significant reduction in lactoferrin levels in pasteurized milk compared to raw milk, except for one study using UV-C pasteurization found that lactoferrin is significantly decreased after pasteurization [ [65](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27490567)]. In milk and [ colostrum](https://selfhacked.com/blog/colostrum/), lactoferrin is at the concentration of 7g/L [ [66](http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/07315724.2001.10719173)]. Digestion and Absorption About 60 - 80% of ingested lactoferrin from cow's milk survives stomach digestion in humans depending on whether it is bound to iron [ [67](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11481401)]. Some lactoferrin is digested by stomach enzymes like pepsin. This digestion results in smaller proteins or peptides which have stronger antimicrobial activities than the protein itself. Lactoferrin and its peptides are absorbed either just through intestinal cells or through the [Intelectin 1](https://selfdecode.com/gene/itln1/?utm_source=seo&utm_medium=selfhacked&utm_campaign=id00002) receptor. It gets incorporated into the lymphatic system before entering the systemic circulation. It can also be transported into the gut immune system [ [68](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21895541)].
